8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (20:33): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: Just realized that the code you gave me ("?label /for/ :invalid") won't work for use case #2: Targeting elements that come after a label with an input child (<p>Label <label><input></label> <small>Text</small></p>)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:34): 8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0: Correct.  This is why I don't like the subject indicator very much.  It would be better to use :has().
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:34): 8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0: "label:has( :scope /for/ :invalid ) + small
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:34): Alternately, use Hierarchies to get the same functionality (this is silly, though):
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (20:34): can:has(cheezeburger)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:35): "?label /for/ :invalid { & + small { <properties go here> } }
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (20:35): But won't both :has and nesting with subject specified lead to parent relationships that vendors have said no to for years due to performance issues?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:36): The subject indicator all by itself leads to those problems.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:36): But yes.  We're trying to push on it to see if they're usable in practice these days.
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (20:36): Well, to an extent, but it isn't in a loop

8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (20:37): Once you add nesting (and force them to use the subject, rather than the normal hierarchy), or add :has(), it will have a loop that will cause *more* of an issue.
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (20:37): I think that's been the main reason behind it (but only one deep isn't as bad).
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (20:38): Whereas if :invalid and all of that was also available to label, this could be avoided
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (20:38): I think it would be an easier idea for vendors to accept, but I could be wrong.
